Award.AwardTitle: Postdoctoral Fellowship: A Clinical Ethnography of Pediatric Medicine

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research will explore cultural ideals of childhood and how they shape and inform pediatric practices to heal children. In addition it will explore how pediatric practices reproduce ideals of childhood. The proposed research will contribute to providing improved support and education for patients' families and the healthcare delivery system for children. It will contribute to the creation of a new model that describes how science and technology in bio-medicine are impacting childhood. Outcomes of the proposed research will be a blog to provide and share information to and between patient families. Publications from this proposed research will educate new patient families, pediatric practitioners, hospital administrators, social workers, child life specialists and educators as to ways to support patients and their families.

The proposed research will study how contemporary constructions of childhood shape medicine and will explore how they are reproduced through the everyday routines and practices of a pediatric hospital in the United States. The proposed research will employ ethnographic research methods, including one year of observation in a pediatric hospital, visits to other pediatric hospitals, and interviews with hospital staff and patient families. It will investigate how the process of healing children is understood and actualized by pediatric practitioners, patients and their families. The proposed research will contribute to improving healthcare delivery through data that will inform the administration of treatment protocols, the management of hospital resources, older children transitioning to adult care, and the identification of inequities in the distribution of healthcare.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

In 2016, C.J. Pascoe and Liberty Barnes launched an ethnographic study of University Children’s Hospital, a 150-bed public teaching hospital in a mid-size city on the West Coast, to better understand the development and culture of pediatric hospitals in the United States. The study was funded by the Science, Technology & Society (STS) program in the Division of Social and Economic Sciences of the National Science Foundation. The funding provided Dr. Barnes with a postdoctoral fellowship at the University of Oregon from September 2016 to August 2018 to conduct the study under the mentorship of Professor Pascoe. This research study, which was guided by a list of 26 research questions, was inspired by one simple question: Why do children’s hospitals feel different than adult hospitals?

Dr. Barnes spent 500 hours conducting observations inside University Children’s Hospital (UCH). She took fieldnotes as she shadowed hospital staff on morning rounds; attended grand rounds, board meetings, and seminars; attended fundraising events; and helped with holiday donation intake. She shadowed doctors, nurses, technicians, child life specialists, social workers, and various other staff in multiple departments, including Hematology and Oncology, Pulmonology, Perinatology, Palliative Care, Nephrology, Neurosurgery, Emergency, Child Life, Social Work, Chaplaincy, and Food Services. Additionally, Dr. Barnes conducted semi-structured interviews with 82 individuals, including hospital staff, patients, and patients’ family members. Interviews were recorded and transcribed. Outputs from this research study are based on the qualitative data gathered during observations in the field and transcripts from interviews.

Outputs from this study are currently in progress. They will include at least three published articles and one monograph. The first article, titled “Holiday Gifting at a Children’s Hospital: Sacred Ritual, Sacred Space,” has been accepted for publication in The Journal of Contemporary Ethnography. This first article presents a departure from the biomedicalization theories that have framed medical sociology for the past few decades. Drawing on Emile Durkheim’s notion of ‘the sacred,’ we break new ground in medical sociology by arguing that children’s hospitals are more than bureaucratic medico-scientific institutions. Rather, they are sacred spaces and the moral heart of their local communities. In an era of secularization, segregation, and political division, pediatric hospitals serve as emblems of unity and represent shared cultural values regarding children’s lives and the innocence and purity of childhood values across seemingly disparate social groups.

The first published article examines the relationship between children’s hospitals and their hometown communities. This Durkheimian analysis sets the stage for forthcoming outputs which examine the philosophies of care that guide pediatric practitioners in the treatment of sick children. In recent years, medical sociologists and anthropologists have demonstrated how bureaucratic cost-cutting measures, automation, digitization, and complicated health insurance programs within the biomedical industrial complex have undermined medical goals. Pediatric medicine represents a site of resistance, a place where practitioners refuse to compromise their professional ethics and integrity by spending time with patients, advocating for them, and ignoring institutional bottom-line financial goals. This resistance is grounded in fundamental cultural beliefs about the sacredness of children’s lives and childhood.

Biomedicine has been extensively critiqued for its myopic understanding of human health, focusing on measurable physical etiologies and advocating treatments that address very specific etiologies and their symptoms. Pediatric medicine subscribes to a more holistic approach to understanding human health, development, and healing. Pediatric practitioners believe that physical, emotional, mental, social, and cognitive health and development are inextricably integrated in children. They recognize the social determinants of health as integral to the health and development of their patients and are committed to social justice, social welfare, public education, environmental protection, safe housing, and immigration reform.

Importantly, practitioners, patients, and patients’ families all reported that mental and emotional health were essential to physical healing. Love, compassion, and human connection were commonly recurring theme in interviews with patients, their families, and medical providers. Patient families believed that the love of doctors and nurses was an essential ingredient in their child’s healing process. Children reported that they loved medical staff and felt loved by them. Medical staff reported that their love for children drove them to careers in pediatric medicine, and that they loved their patients. In clinic appointments and on rounds, providers told parents that they loved their children. Many interviewees explained that the loving relationship between patients and providers was what distinguished pediatric medicine from adult medicine.

These findings will be disseminated in two articles: one that examines how children with chronic or terminal illnesses experience children’s hospitals and one that examines how pediatric practioners participate in the social construction of childhood. Ultimately, all of the findings will be disseminated in a book, tentatively titled, “Pediatric Love: How Children’s Hospitals Are Saving America.”
